articles.headline: Trump’s Hopes of Being the ‘Neutral Guy’ in the Mideast Seem Long Gone
articles.snippet: Hosting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, the president said he still had “a good chance” of forging peace, but a deal seems further away than ever.
articles.abstract: Hosting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, the president said he still had “a good chance” of forging peace, but a deal seems further away than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the midst of his campaign, President Trump vowed to bring peace to the Middle East by playing it down the middle between Israel and the Palestinians. “Let me be sort of a neutral guy,” he said. Two years later, any hopes of being the neutral guy are long gone.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: Puerto Rico’s Positive Business Slogans Can’t Keep the Lights On
articles.snippet: Five months after Hurricane Maria, businesses small and large are still grappling with a lack of electricity, worker shortages and a gutted tourism industry.
articles.abstract: Five months after Hurricane Maria, businesses small and large are still grappling with a lack of electricity, worker shortages and a gutted tourism industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The message coming out of an investment conference here in February was simple and optimistic: “Puerto Rico is open for business.” Attendees noted San Juan’s crowded restaurants and traffic-choked streets. The capital city seemed to be bustling.

articles.headline: Behind Public Persona, the Real Xi Jinping Is a Guarded Secret
articles.snippet: As China’s president moves to become leader for life, it is striking how little is known about him, despite his having held the country’s highest posts since 2012.
articles.abstract: As China’s president moves to become leader for life, it is striking how little is known about him, despite his having held the country’s highest posts since 2012.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — One Sunday last month, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, traveled to a village in the mountains of Sichuan Province. He wore an olive overcoat with a fur collar, which he kept zipped up even when he entered an adobe house to meet with villagers. Around an indoor fire pit, he sat among a circle of people wearing traditional clothes of the Yi minority group.

articles.headline: Big Investors Have Clout. They Can Use It With Gun Makers.
articles.snippet: Investment firms like Larry Fink’s BlackRock have preached social responsibility. With guns, they can use their influence to achieve it.
articles.abstract: Investment firms like Larry Fink’s BlackRock have preached social responsibility. With guns, they can use their influence to achieve it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past several weeks, there has been a lot of talk about investors ridding themselves of their shares in gun manufacturers and retailers after the school shooting in Parkland, Fla. A number of public pension funds, like those in the state of Connecticut, have discussed the prospect of selling their shares.

articles.headline: Trump Reaffirms Commitment to Tariffs but Opens Door to Compromise
articles.snippet: Republicans intensified pressure on President Trump to relent on his steel and aluminum tariffs, while the president indicated he might provide exemptions for certain countries.
articles.abstract: Republicans intensified pressure on President Trump to relent on his steel and aluminum tariffs, while the president indicated he might provide exemptions for certain countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: (Update, March 6: Gary D. Cohn, President Trump’s top economic adviser and a key pro-trade voice in the White House, said Tuesday that he would resign. Read more »)
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: New Foils for the Right: Google and Facebook
articles.snippet: A new documentary from Peter Schweizer — the man who gave the world “Clinton Cash” — signals a revised strategy for conservatives in the culture wars.
articles.abstract: A new documentary from Peter Schweizer — the man who gave the world “Clinton Cash” — signals a revised strategy for conservatives in the culture wars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Conservatives are zeroing in on a new enemy in the political culture wars: Big Tech.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Herrman

articles.headline: In Poisoning of Sergei Skripal, Russian Ex-Spy, U.K. Sees Cold War Echoes
articles.snippet: Britain assigned the counterterrorism police to investigate the sudden illness of the spy, Sergei V. Skripal, and his daughter.
articles.abstract: Britain assigned the counterterrorism police to investigate the sudden illness of the spy, Sergei V. Skripal, and his daughter.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALISBURY, England — The gentle stroll from Zizzi’s, a restaurant in the center of this sleepy cathedral town, to Sainsbury’s, a popular nearby supermarket, could scarcely be less remarkable. Turn right past the town library, through a covered alleyway, past the gym on the left, over a bubbling mill stream and — 90 seconds later — you have arrived.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Richard Pérez-Peña
